title: How to Check the Event Log on PC or Mac

steps.title: Open the Windows search bar.
steps.content: Open the Windows search bar. If you see the search bar next to the menu, skip to the next step. Otherwise, press ⊞ Win + S to open it now.

steps.title: Type administrative into the search bar.
steps.content: Type administrative into the search bar. A list of matching results will appear.

steps.title: Click Administrative Tools.
steps.content: Click Administrative Tools . This opens an Explorer window that contains several administrative options.

steps.title: Double-click Event Viewer.
steps.content: Double-click Event Viewer . It’s in the main panel. This opens the Event Viewer, where you can view different types of event logs.

steps.title: Click the > next to “Windows Logs.”
steps.content: Click the > next to “Windows Logs.” It’s in the left column. A list of logs that pertain to Windows will appear.

steps.title: Click a log to view its contents.
steps.content: Click a log to view its contents. The log will appear in the main panel.

steps.title: Open the Applications folder on your Mac.
steps.content: Open the Applications folder on your Mac. To do this, click the Go menu and select Applications .

steps.title: Double-click the Utilities folder.
steps.content: Double-click the Utilities folder. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Double-click Console.
steps.content: Double-click Console . This opens the Console app, which is where you can view system diagnostic logs for all sorts of events.

steps.title: Click All Messages.
steps.content: Click All Messages . It’s near the top-left corner of the window, right above the left column. This displays all of the messages recorded by each process.

steps.title: Click Errors and Faults.
steps.content: Click Errors and Faults . It’s next to the “All Messages” button. This refines the log results so it only displays errors.

steps.title: Click a report under the “Reports” header.
steps.content: Click a report under the “Reports” header. This opens reports of system or user/application events in the right panel.
